data.title: Simply explained: Timeline of the Crusades: Facts, Battles, and Leaders (History)
data.meta_description: History: Topics ✓ Revision note ✓ 12 Grades ✓ Overview ✓ Tips ✓ Presentations ✓ Exam Prep ✓ Flashcards ✓ Share Content.
data.text:
Background

The Crusades were a series of religious wars initiated by the Latin Church in the medieval period. The goal was to recapture the Holy Land from Muslim rule. The Crusades spanned several centuries and had a significant impact on the history of Europe, the Middle East, and beyond.

First Crusade Launch Timeline

1071: Seljuk Turks defeat the Byzantine army at the Battle of Manzikert.

March 1095: Envoys from the Byzantine emperor Alexis Comnenus ask Pope Urban II for military aid.

27th November 1095: Pope Urban II launches the First Crusade at the Council of Claremont.

15th July 1099: Crusaders capture Jerusalem.

Second Crusade

December 1144: Edessa falls to Zengi of Aleppo.

1st December 1145: Pope Eugenius III issues the Quantum Praedecessors crusade appeal, launching the Second Crusade.

May-June 1147: Crusader armies from France, Flanders, and Germany depart for the Second Crusade.

October 1147: German army defeated in Asia Minor.

June 1148: Council of Palmarea decides to attack Damascus: the Siege falls, ending the Second Crusade.

Third Crusade

4th July 1187: Battle of Hattin - Christian army wiped out by Saladin, king Guy captured.

October 1187: Fall of Jerusalem; Third Crusade launched by the Pope.

7th September 1191: Battle of Arsuf - Richard I defeats Saladin.

October 1191: First march on Jerusalem turns back.

June 1192: Second march on Jerusalem fails.

5th August 1192: Battle Daffa - Richard I defeats Saladin.

September 1192: Truce arranged: Richard leaves in October, ending the Third Crusade.

Conclusion

The Crusades are a complex and controversial part of history, with multiple political, economic, and social consequences. They were a significant turning point in the relationship between the East and West and had a lasting impact on both Christian and Muslim societies. Understanding the timeline and events of the Crusades is essential for comprehending the broader historical context. For further exploration, a visit to a Crusader museum or a study of the Timeline of the Crusades map can provide valuable insights into this tumultuous period.

Summary - History

The Crusades were a series of religious wars in the medieval period to recapture the Holy Land from Muslim rule

First Crusade launched in 1095 and captured Jerusalem in 1099

Second Crusade launched in 1145 and ended with failed siege of Damascus in 1148

Third Crusade fought battles in 1187 and 1191, ending with a truce in 1192

The Crusades had a lasting impact on Christian and Muslim societies and the relationship between East and West.
